speaker: First Witch
text_entry: SCENE VI. Forres. The palace.

speaker: First Witch
text_entry: Enter LENNOX and another Lord

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: My former speeches have but hit your thoughts,

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Which can interpret further: only, I say,

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Things have been strangely borne. The

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: gracious Duncan

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Was pitied of Macbeth: marry, he was dead:

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: And the right-valiant Banquo walk'd too late;

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Whom, you may say, if't please you, Fleance kill'd,

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: For Fleance fled: men must not walk too late.

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Who cannot want the thought how monstrous

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: It was for Malcolm and for Donalbain

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: To kill their gracious father? damned fact!

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: How it did grieve Macbeth! did he not straight

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: In pious rage the two delinquents tear,

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: That were the slaves of drink and thralls of sleep?

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Was not that nobly done? Ay, and wisely too;

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: For 'twould have anger'd any heart alive

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: To hear the men deny't. So that, I say,

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: He has borne all things well: and I do think

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: That had he Duncan's sons under his key--

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: As, an't please heaven, he shall not--they

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: should find

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: What 'twere to kill a father; so should Fleance.

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: But, peace! for from broad words and 'cause he fail'd

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: His presence at the tyrant's feast, I hear

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Macduff lives in disgrace: sir, can you tell

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Where he bestows himself?

speaker: Lord
text_entry: The son of Duncan,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: From whom this tyrant holds the due of birth

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Lives in the English court, and is received

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Of the most pious Edward with such grace

speaker: Lord
text_entry: That the malevolence of fortune nothing

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Takes from his high respect: thither Macduff

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Is gone to pray the holy king, upon his aid

speaker: Lord
text_entry: To wake Northumberland and warlike Siward:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: That, by the help of these--with Him above

speaker: Lord
text_entry: To ratify the work--we may again

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Give to our tables meat, sleep to our nights,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Free from our feasts and banquets bloody knives,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Do faithful homage and receive free honours:

speaker: Lord
text_entry: All which we pine for now: and this report

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Hath so exasperate the king that he

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Prepares for some attempt of war.

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Sent he to Macduff?

speaker: Lord
text_entry: He did: and with an absolute 'Sir, not I,'

speaker: Lord
text_entry: The cloudy messenger turns me his back,

speaker: Lord
text_entry: And hums, as who should say 'You'll rue the time

speaker: Lord
text_entry: That clogs me with this answer.'

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: And that well might

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Advise him to a caution, to hold what distance

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: His wisdom can provide. Some holy angel

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Fly to the court of England and unfold

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: His message ere he come, that a swift blessing

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: May soon return to this our suffering country

speaker: LENNOX
text_entry: Under a hand accursed!

speaker: Lord
text_entry: I'll send my prayers with him.

speaker: Lord
text_entry: Exeunt
